question.answerText: Minister of State at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade  I am concerned at the law passed in October by the transitional parliament in Mali that criminalised homosexuality. The promotion and protection of human rights is a domestic and foreign policy priority for the Government, underpinned by our commitment to universal human rights. We recognise that LGBTQI+ people continue to suffer disproportionate levels of violence and face systemic discrimination in many countries, and we are active in advocating for LGBTQI+ rights.  Ireland strongly supports efforts internationally to promote and protect the rights of LGBTQI+ persons, including through the European Union, the UN Human Rights Council and the UN General Assembly. We have engaged actively with the UN Independent Expert on Protection against Violence and Discrimination based on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity, including at the June 2025 Human Rights Council. Ireland has also made defending the rights of LGBTIQ+ persons one of our top priorities in the campaign for election to the Human Rights Council.  At the most recent Human Rights Council Universal Periodic Review of Mali in May 2023, Ireland called upon the Malian authorities to bring to justice all perpetrators of violations and abuses of human rights. We expressed concern about constraints on freedom of expression and the documented increase in gender-based violence in Mali. Ireland also encouraged the incorporation of the prohibition and punishment of all forms of sexual and gender-based violence into future legislation.  Ireland will continue to advocate in international fora for the promotion and protection of human rights, paying particular attention to the rights of LGBTQI+ people in the face of systemic discrimination.  The Government's international development cooperation programme, Irish Aid, is providing support for civil society organisations and human rights defenders working to defend LGBTQI+ rights in developing countries. We have remained steadfast in our commitment to international development, and to the promotion and protection of human rights globally. We will continue to support our partners working at the frontlines to promote human rights and accountability.

question.answerText: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade  The protection and promotion of human rights, including the freedom of religion and belief, is a core pillar of Ireland's approach to foreign policy. Ireland strongly condemns all forms of persecution on the basis of religion or belief, irrespective of where they occur or who the victims are. This would include situations where Christians face persecution for exercising the right to practice their faith.  The Government regularly raises concerns regarding human rights with China in bilateral meetings and in appropriate international fora. Ireland consistently raises issues relating to restrictions on freedom of religion or belief in China at the UN Human Rights Council (HRC), including in our most recent Item 4 statement at the 60th session in September 2025. Ireland also joined the European Union (EU) statement at the 60th session of the HRC, which reiterated the rights of persons belonging to religious groups in China to conduct their basic affairs without interference.  In addition to our bilateral engagement, Ireland also addresses human rights in China as a member of the EU. At the 40th EU-China Human Rights Dialogue in June 2025, the EU expressed its concerns for the particularly vulnerable situation of persons belonging to religious, ethnic and linguistic minorities in China.  Ireland will continue to address issues relating to restrictions on freedom of religion or belief and other human rights concerns with China, both bilaterally and as a member of the EU, through our contacts in Dublin and Beijing, and in the relevant multilateral fora.

question.answerText: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade  As we prepare to mark the 70th anniversary of Ireland's membership of the United Nations, it is appropriate to reflect on all the UN has achieved, and the important contribution Ireland has made to the UN, not least through the service of our peacekeepers. The UN and the Charter of the United Nations lie at the heart of Ireland's foreign policy.  It is also the case that, eighty years since the UN's creation, the institution needs to continue to grow and adapt to ensure that it is able to respond effectively to the myriad of challenges our world faces.  I welcome the UN80 reform initiative that was announced by the UN Secretary General in March this year which aims to develop a more agile, effective and responsive organisation. Ireland wants to see a UN that is accountable, eliminates duplication, strengthens cooperation; and most importantly delivers on the ground for those most in need.  Ireland supports the work of the UN80 initiative and is actively engaging across all work streams. Ireland is also clear that reform cannot come at the cost of UN core values. The work of the UN on important issues such as human rights, gender equality and climate action must be protected and advanced in line with the Sustainable Development Goals. Ireland will continue to invest in multilateralism, a rules-based international order, and a healthy United Nations to lead it. There is no other path to underpin our security, prosperity and well-being.

question.answerText: Minister for Transport  As Minister for Transport, I have responsibility for policy and overall funding in relation to Active Travel infrastructure. The National Transport Authority (NTA) along with the relevant local authorities are responsible for the development and delivery of individual projects.  The Government is committed to promoting and enabling walking and cycling across the country with approximately €360 million provided for Active Travel and Greenways this year alone, supporting projects in every Local Authority. The vast majority of this funding is allocated to the National Transport Authority (NTA) through the Department of Transport for its Active Travel Infrastructure Programme. I was delighted to secure similar funding for Active Travel and Greenways in Budget 2026, meaning that we can continue to progress walking and cycling projects around the country into next year.  As part of the allocations determination, the NTA liaises with each local authority to fully understand the projects being proposed by the local authority and its considerations in terms of priorities.  In general, the main focus of active travel investment will be to support high quality walking and cycling infrastructure, for everyday trips, in villages, towns and cities, particularly in designated growth settlements, with a view to promoting the greatest potential modal shift to active travel.  Given the ramping up of activities over the last few years in the Active Travel area, the number of projects being progressed now exceeds the level of funding made available to the NTA. Accordingly, the NTA is unable to fully fund all proposed Active Travel projects and has to prioritise certain projects over others in order to remain within its allocated budget. While a project may not be selected by the NTA for funding in a particular year, it may be funded in subsequent years.  The 2026 allocations for the Active Travel Infrastructure Programme will be announced early in the new year.  Separately, it is my understanding that the restoration and maintenance of the footbridge over the Ounavarra River would fall under the remit of Coillte and the Department of Rural and Community Development and the Gaeltacht.

question.answerText: Minister for Transport  The Agreement on Air Transport between the European Community and its Member States and Canada provides the legal framework for scheduled services to operate between Ireland and Canada.  Ultimately, the operation of any scheduled air service is a commercial decision for airlines, in consultation with airports and other market actors, based on the commercial viability of the route in question and other operational factors. I do not have a role in such decisions.  The summer season in 2025 saw offerings from four airlines from Dublin to six different Canadian destinations, with St. John's an additional destination on offer to passengers this year. All four airlines offered daily flights to Toronto. Frequencies on a number of services also increased compared to the equivalent season in 2024. Year-round services from Dublin to Toronto are currently operated by both Aer Lingus and Air Canada.

question.answerText: Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment  The Government acknowledges that the retail sector contributes to the economy of every city, town and village in Ireland. The sector provides highly important employment with over 220,000 people directly employed in retail.  The programme for Government is clear on the intention to support small businesses and as the Minister of State with responsibility for retail, I am aware of the issues facing retailers.  The broad range of supports for the retail sector, including training programmes and funding to help retailers adapt to new challenges and opportunities in retail, can be found on the national enterprise hub, NEH. The NEH is an all-of-government service staffed by expertly trained advisers and is focused on helping businesses to access a range of Government supports. The hub brings together information and resources of over 250 Government supports from 32 different Departments and State agencies. The grow digital voucher offers up to €5,000 to small businesses, including retailers, to invest in technology such as e-commerce software, online booking systems and stock control, which are designed to enhance productivity and competitiveness.  The energy efficiency grant provides up to a maximum of €10,000, with a 75% contribution rate from the Government to support investment in technologies and equipment identified in a green for business, GreenStart or Sustainable Energy Authority of Ireland, SEAI, energy audit. The aim of the scheme is to reduce the impact of enterprises on the environment, thereby increasing the agility and resilience of these businesses.  In 2024, the Government introduced the power up grant and the increased cost of business, ICOB, scheme, which paid out over €400 million to businesses. Included in this was a second ICOB payment and a €4,000 power-up grant for businesses in the retail sector. The Department opened a reclassification appeals process this July, which allowed businesses in the retail sector that had initially misclassified their business category an opportunity to reclassify.  The cost of business advisory forum has been established, comprising SME and industry representative organisations, and the forum held its inaugural meeting in July. A report is due to the Government in the first quarter of next year, which will outline the forum's findings and highlight the steps that can be taken to mitigate rising costs.

question.answerText: Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment  Ireland has a proven track-record in attracting high-value, cutting edge industry to locate and invest across its regions, and contribute to national prosperity. This includes energy intensive industrial developments in strategically important sectors such as data centres.  The construction and operation of data centres have positively contributed to the Irish economy over the last decade through direct employment and the provision of critical digital infrastructure. Data centres form the infrastructure backbone of Ireland’s digital infrastructure and are a critical enabler of our modern economy. Their presence strengthens Ireland’s position as a strategic international location for enterprise activity, including within the ICT, finance and manufacturing sectors. Data Centres underpin the delivery of essential services that citizens and businesses depend on daily, ranging from online banking, e-commerce, and cloud-based applications to accessing health and public services, and streaming entertainment.  Beyond their technological role, data centres contribute significantly to Ireland’s economy. Their construction and operation contribute to Ireland’s GVA, creates high-quality jobs and support development of a high-skilled and sophisticated supply chain, that now also exports globally. Data Centres are not only infrastructure assets; they are catalysts for innovation, enabling businesses to adopt cutting-edge technologies and develop new products and services.  The ability to host data centres in Ireland has become an important part of our value proposition for attracting and retaining foreign direct investment from leading global technology firms and reinforcing Ireland’s position as a trusted hub for digital infrastructure and innovation. Looking ahead, as AI and cloud computing continue to reshape industries, the role of data centres will become even more critical to maintaining Ireland’s global competitiveness.  The ‘Harnessing Digital Strategy’ sets out Ireland’s ambition to continue as a European and global digital leader and our commitment to progressing the digital transformation of our economy and society. As global digital transformation accelerates, the strategic importance of data centres continues to grow. Artificial Intelligence (AI), machine learning, and big data analytics will require vast computing power and secure, scalable storage solutions. Data centres provide this foundation, ensuring Ireland remains competitive in a rapidly evolving digital landscape.  The operation and development of data centres must also align with Ireland’s legally binding climate objectives and the need to maintain robust energy security. Our data centre policy is underpinned by the 2022 Government Statement on the Role of Data Centres in Ireland’s Enterprise Strategy, which prioritises energy security and projects primarily powered by renewables.  I have also engaged with the CRU on their proposed revision of Connection Policy for Large Energy Users (LEUs), and expect that this will be progressed in near future. The Government has committed to establishing a plan that will guide the short- and medium-term development of data centre and energy intensive manufacturing industry infrastructure in alignment with Ireland’s decarbonisation objectives and growing the knowledge-based economy. The plan is due to be published by my Department in early 2026.

question.answerText: Minister for Social Protection  Under the Future Building Initiative, a dedicated team staffed by Intreo from the Department of Social Protection, SOLAS and the Education and Training Boards, supports recruitment and training for the construction industry. The Department of Social Protection is leading the initiative to drive national and international recruitment activities. Future Building has to date been supported by the Department of the Taoiseach under the Government’s Housing for All Implementation Fund.  On an ongoing basis Future Building works with many construction companies, sharing construction vacancies with many EU/EEA countries through the EURES (European Employment Services) platform, and matching interested jobseekers with relevant employers. Future Building also organises events where construction firms showcase opportunities, apprenticeships, and graduate programmes.  In November the EURES team in my Department, in conjunction with Crosscare Irish Diaspora Support Project, organised "Failte Back". This was an online job day aimed at the Irish diaspora across the world planning on returning to Ireland. Thirty-nine construction employers participated in the event which offered direct access to employers and relocation advice.  The Department of Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science is currently implementing the Careers in Construction Action Plan, which comprises 20 actions that relate to structural, promotional, and training activities to minimise barriers, promote career opportunities, and make construction jobs more attractive to women.  Among these actions are several campaign initiatives supported by the 2024 and 2025 Housing for All Implementation Fund. These include the "Building Heroes" peer-to-peer social media campaign, a documentary on careers in construction for second-level schools, and the "Build Back Home" campaign focused on Irish construction workers abroad.

question.answerText: Minister of State at the Department of Justice  While my Department is the competent authority for the import and export of firearms, An Garda Síochána has a range of functions with regard to the operation of firearms legislation, including the issuing of firearms certificates and authorisations and is the competent authority for the licensing of firearms within the State. question.answerText: Tánaiste and Minister for Finance  As the Deputy will be aware, the Programme for Government, includes a commitment to “consider measures, in conjunction with the Department of Finance, to encourage gym membership and active participation in sport and exercise.”  In line with best practice, and as with all proposals for the introduction of new tax measures or the amendment of existing tax reliefs, the proposal should be assessed in accordance with the Department of Finance Tax Expenditure Guidelines.  Officials in my Department considered the matter as part of the annual Tax Strategy Group process in July this year, in chapter 10 of the 2025 Tax Strategy Group Income Tax paper which is available at:  www.gov.ie/en/department-of-finance/collections/budget-2026-tax-strategy-group-papers/.  I would also note that the tax code already provides for a number of fitness based measures more generally.  For example, the Cycle to Work Scheme provides that bicycles and associated safety equipment provided by employers to employees will be treated as a tax exempt benefit-in-kind subject to certain conditions being met.  In addition, the Accelerated Capital Allowances scheme for Childcare facilities and Fitness Centres encourages employers to develop childcare facilities and fitness centres onsite for their employees. The scheme provides accelerated allowances for qualifying buildings or structures over a seven year period and accelerated allowances for related equipment at 100 per cent in year one.  Furthermore, the private gym sector already receives tax-based public support through a reduced rate of VAT of 9 per cent on membership fees. It is estimated that this reduced rate saves private gym operators and gym members in the order of €32 million per annum.  Further decisions regarding taxation matters will be made as usual in the context of the Annual Budget and Finance Bill process.
